paragraphs.name: 669c
paragraphs.text: Great advice. I’m looking forward to your future articles. Bottom line — you truly need to find a passion.

paragraphs.name: e5e5
paragraphs.text: I suggest that you enjoy life and stop thinking about growing your net worth as fast or much as possible. If you really had 5 million dollars, it probably wouldn’t take hardcore efforts to increase your net worth at a moderate speed safely.

paragraphs.name: 5e5e
paragraphs.text: In addition to reading about Warren Buffett, you may consider reading up on Trend Following. It’s principles transcend investing and apply to all facets of life: 1) trade with the trend; 2) let winners run; 3) cut losses quickly and 4) manage risk. Trend Following, for most people, is much more practical and simpler than trying to emulate guys like Warren Buffett. And there are several Trend Following investors who have performed just as well as him over their careers.

paragraphs.name: 39ec
paragraphs.text: I will say this: it’s one thing to learn about yourself in your world, and a whole other thing to learn about yourself in relation to others from many different worlds.

It was not till I had a little more money than I actually needed that I realised I had a deep sadness that had always been there but I was always too busy getting by to pay attention to it. I also suddenly had the time to notice what, in life, had given me lasting pleasure and satisfaction. Some of your responses have veiled anger towards you. I remember when I might have responded that way as well.

paragraphs.name: 8a07
paragraphs.text: That’s the point at which I stopped reading.

paragraphs.name: a653
paragraphs.text: I learned another big lesson from this. I now never help people who don’t ask me for help, and even then I only help them to the extent that they ask. I also look for ways that I can help that don’t compromise my own position, and that require the least outlay of my money, time, and effort.

paragraphs.name: a314
paragraphs.text: I am sure bad experiences in trying to help others can really make this difficult! But any small act of kindness is better than nothing

Maybe it’s time for you to actually do real charity work my friend. With people not having internet and regular hot meals. It’s not about buying somebody a house, it’s about doing the simplest of things like sitting down with a welfare couple and simply listening to them. With them, stock broking fees and your miserable money troubles is something abstract that don’t exist. They don’t want your money.

paragraphs.name: d3c5
paragraphs.text: txs for sharing this … here’s my story https://medium.com/@dve845/my-long-hard-road-to-financial-freedom-fc85722ba4ca#.q2916aly4

paragraphs.name: ecf0
paragraphs.text: Duncan, wow! Thanks for sharing the dark side of the Silicon Valley dream. We knew several people who made it big during the dotcom era, then completely dropped off the grid and out of our lives. We wondered, was it us? Now I see that maybe it wasn’t. I always wondered what people went through after the IPO, thanks for telling your story.

paragraphs.name: 5ba5
paragraphs.text: People do act weirdly about money, that’s true.. cause it’s tied to a lot of power.

paragraphs.name: 811d
paragraphs.text: Great insights Duncan. Thank you very much.

paragraphs.name: a653
paragraphs.text: I learned another big lesson from this. I now never help people who don’t ask me for help, and even then I only help them to the extent that they ask. I also look for ways that I can help that don’t compromise my own position, and that require the least outlay of my money, time, and effort.

paragraphs.name: f1ae
paragraphs.text: Thanks for the suggestion. I’ll take a look. I want to clarify that what Warren Buffet recommends for most people (index funds) is not what he does. His form of value investing requires deep understanding of the company and market in order to be able to buy high-quality companies, at prices that are below their intrinsic value, and then hold them for very long periods.

c80b3a8b7553.title: Thank you! Excited to deliver them.

content.subtitle: I will say this: it’s one thing to learn about yourself in your world, and a whole other thing to learn about yourself in relation to…

paragraphs.name: f753
paragraphs.text: I won’t comment on ‘happiness’ or ‘success’ or ‘purpose’ because those are mostly relative concepts tied to individual experience. Popular culture seems quite confused about what those things even mean in terms of socioeconomic realities. Don’t take my word for it, though: Spend time in Topeka, Detroit or East Camden and you can see for yourself.

paragraphs.name: ecf0
paragraphs.text: Duncan, wow! Thanks for sharing the dark side of the Silicon Valley dream. We knew several people who made it big during the dotcom era, then completely dropped off the grid and out of our lives. We wondered, was it us? Now I see that maybe it wasn’t. I always wondered what people went through after the IPO, thanks for telling your story.

paragraphs.text: I am not sure how I feel about this — I feel in this era of capitalist ideals it is healthy, if not necessary to start focusing on how we can help others. Of course financially is only 1 area of this, and i agree that we have to help others help themselves if we really want to make a lasting change.

paragraphs.name: 669c
paragraphs.text: Great advice. I’m looking forward to your future articles. Bottom line — you truly need to find a passion.

About international fees — I recently realized my mother was losing out a lot with Bank of America. Check out TransferWise (https://transferwise.com). It was started by early Skype employees. Gives you the market rate on currencies.

paragraphs.name: 7cae
paragraphs.text: I’m running low on money at this moment, and I won’t be able to afford a new computer for years. This really sucks. I need a powerful computer to do some work, and my machine’s processing power is “severely” limited.
